body:
> I would like the ability to mark a function as a candidate for JIT prior to execution.

You could try PowerShell classes.

The Engine WG discussed this issue today. While there is a continuing desire to improve PowerShell performance, this scenario is not a priority for the team at the moment.  However, we believe there is existing infrastructure support e.g. `CompileInterpretChoice.AlwaysCompile` that "might" make this easy for the community to implement as an "up-for-grabs" experimental feature. 

We would appreciate having a repeatable repro script to help evaluate this scenario in terms of such an experimental feature. And with a repro script, we may be able to profile it at a lower-level to determine the root of the perf issue.  

The issue you mention about lack of docs on JIT behavior, should be filed in the [PowerShell-Docs repo](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/PowerShell-Docs/issues).  BTW the experimental feature should provide some basic documentation on when the feature should and should not be used.

> However, we believe there is existing infrastructure support e.g. `CompileInterpretChoice.AlwaysCompile` that "might" make this easy for the community to implement as an "up-for-grabs" experimental feature.

Oh, currently there is a well perf balance in PowerShell with heuristics  when compile + internal caches vs interpret. It's non-trivial to keep that equilibrium.
Perhaps we could benefit from the modern capabilities of the .Net jitting.

The behavior you're observing stems from resolution of the `$List.$Key` expressions - it's sending PowerShell on a "detour" via the extended type system to resolve the appropriate hashtable entry. 

Replace all 6 occurrences of `$List.$Key` with `$List[$Key]` and you should see a much better and more consistent performance profile.
